Table of Contents

Enum FeedHealthStatus

Namespace
NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums
Assembly
NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.dll

Represents the health and operational status of an RSS/Atom feed, determined by the outcome of recent update/fetch attempts and overall accessibility.

public enum FeedHealthStatus

Fields

Error = 2

The feed has encountered multiple consecutive failures or exhibits a high error rate in recent attempts. Automatic updates are significantly restricted.

Behavior:

  • Polling interval is greatly increased or switched to manual-only (configurable).
  • Prominent error indicators in UI (red icon, "Error" label).
  • Exponential backoff or circuit-breaker logic is active.
  • Notifications are usually suppressed until recovery is detected.

When assigned:

  • After 3–8 consecutive failures (exact threshold configurable).
  • Persistent issues: 4xx/5xx errors, timeouts, SSL problems, malformed XML, etc.
Healthy = 0

The feed is updating successfully with no significant issues detected in recent attempts.

Behavior:

  • Standard polling interval is used (default or user-defined).
  • No warning indicators are displayed in the UI.
  • Full eligibility for background refresh, article parsing, and notifications.

When assigned:

  • After multiple consecutive successful fetches.
  • Error rate in the recent window is zero or negligible.
Invalid = 4

The feed URL is invalid, permanently inaccessible, or points to content that cannot be processed as a valid syndication feed.

Behavior:

  • No further automatic refresh attempts are scheduled.
  • Even manual refresh may be blocked or heavily warned against.
  • Strong error UI state ("Invalid", "Gone", red indicators).
  • Feed is typically hidden from active views by default (configurable).

When assigned:

  • Permanent HTTP errors (410 Gone, consistent 404).
  • DNS failures, invalid SSL certificates, wrong content type (HTML instead of XML).
  • Valid 200 response but content is not parseable as RSS/Atom/JSON Feed after retries.

Business note: Invalid is generally a terminal state — recovery requires user correction or deletion.

Paused = 3

The feed has been manually paused or disabled by the user. No automatic refresh activity occurs.

Behavior:

  • Completely excluded from all refresh queues and background tasks.
  • No network requests are made until the user explicitly resumes the feed.
  • UI displays paused state (grayed out, pause icon).
  • Existing articles and metadata remain accessible in read-only mode.

When assigned:

  • User explicitly pauses the feed (e.g., too noisy, seasonal, temporary irrelevance).
  • Some import flows (e.g. OPML) may initialize feeds as Paused.

Important: System logic must never automatically resume a Paused feed.

Warning = 1

The feed remains operational but exhibits intermittent problems (occasional failures, slow responses, partial content, rate limiting, transient HTTP errors, etc.).

Behavior:

  • Polling frequency may be moderately reduced (configurable).
  • Subtle warning indicators appear in the UI (yellow/orange badge or icon).
  • Mild retry backoff may begin on individual failures.
  • Still fully eligible for notifications and content processing.

When assigned:

  • Recent error rate falls in the approximate 10–40% range (thresholds configurable).
  • Temporary issues at the feed provider (rate limits, unstable hosting, etc.).

Recommendation: Prolonged Warning states often precede degradation to Error.

Remarks

This enumeration drives multiple critical behaviors across the application:

  • Whether the feed remains eligible for automatic background polling
  • Visual indicators in the user interface (colors, icons, status badges)
  • Retry frequency, exponential backoff, or circuit-breaker strategies during failures
  • Generation (or suppression) of user notifications and alerts
  • Filtering and sorting logic in feed lists, dashboards, and management views (e.g. "show only healthy feeds")

The status is automatically evaluated and updated by the feed synchronization service after each refresh attempt. It is not based solely on the most recent fetch, but rather considers a sliding window of recent attempts — typically the last 3 to 10 fetches (the exact window size and weighting logic are configurable in the refresh policy settings).

Key business rules and invariants:

  • Only feeds in Healthy or Warning states are eligible for regular automatic polling under normal conditions.
  • Feeds in Error or Invalid states trigger progressive restrictions: longer intervals, exponential backoff, or complete temporary exclusion from refresh queues.
  • Paused is a user-controlled state that unconditionally blocks all automatic and background refresh activity — the system must never transition a Paused feed to another state without explicit user intervention via the UI.
  • Most state transitions are driven by observed fetch results, except for Paused, which is exclusively set or cleared by direct user action.

These rules help balance reliability, resource usage, and user experience while preventing unnecessary network requests to broken or intentionally disabled feeds.
